awd_titl_txt: Sustained Activity Mechanisms for Neurally Encoding Linguistic Structure
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will examine how the human brain implements the short-term memory representations necessary for comprehending language. In particular, the proposed experiments will investigate how sustained increases in neural activity contribute to language understanding, by recording brain activity as adults comprehend structured sentences. In so doing, this work will speak to questions about the role of sustained neural activity in short-term memory in cognition more broadly, which is currently the subject of much debate in the field. The basic research proposed here will ultimately pave the way for a better understanding of the language deficits associated with working memory problems in neurocognitive disorders such as aphasia and schizophrenia, as well as providing more fine-grained neural measures for evaluating language comprehension abilities in populations undergoing first and second language acquisition. The project will also provide numerous training opportunities for students in a technical and highly interdisciplinary research area that draws upon the fields of linguistics, cognitive psychology, computational linguistics, and cognitive neuroscience. 

A key methodological element of the current project is the use of multimodal neuroimaging, which integrates data from a range of techniques (electroencephalography, magnetoencephalography, and functional MRI) in order to precisely identify relevant neural activity both in time and in brain space. These techniques are used to evaluate prior proposals that sustained activity in several brain regions (left inferior frontal cortex and left posterior temporal cortex) is what allows humans to represent relations between different parts of a sentence during language comprehension. Critically, the project builds on foundational work from linguistics and computational linguistics to devise structured language materials that can effectively probe different hypotheses about these neural mechanisms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Human language comprehension requires integrating many separate pieces of information across the several seconds in which a sentence is pronounced, to form structured mental representations of the sentence and the speaker's meaning. This project used neural measurements during comprehension (electroencephalography and magnetoencephalography) to understand whether and how sustained neural firing is used by human comprehenders to maintain these representations. The results of our EEG and MEG experiments provided evidence that sustained neural firing is not necessary for computing and maintaining the sentence structure and form across time, but that it may be more important for computations over the meaning and for maintaining a working memory representation of the current conversation or text, and that these neural operations may be related to those that are used to maintain and update visual scene representations of attended objects and their locations. This project also investigated the units of neural representation in language comprehension. In contrast to the written-language intuition that sentences are composed of discrete 'words', our experimental and theoretical work suggests that the natural neural representation of language relates separate, non-isomorphic units at the sound and meaning level. This is important because many of the world's languages are not organized around 'words' of the English kind, and so the correct theory of how the human brain supports language must be able to account for those cases. We validated a new MEG measurement technique for evaluating neural activity in continuous speech comprehension of an audiobook which doesn't require breaking the neural response up according to 'words' and can thus be ported across different languages more easily. This alternative framework provides possibilities for interpreting the language deficits observed in disorders like aphasia slightly differently, not as deficits in the ability to activate or select 'words', but as deficits in the procedures that translate between different representational formats. This project contributed to training and educating an interdisciplinary workforce. The many graduate and undergraduate students who were involved in the research learned how to integrate theory and methods from linguistics, cognitive psychology, cognitive neuroscience, vision sciences, and computational science. The PI and upper-level PhD students developed new materials for multiple interdisciplinary courses and seminars at the graduate and undergraduate level that were directly inspired and informed by the insights and findings of the project, and which impacted many students beyond those directly involved in the research.
